vision.notes: Sensory capabilities in Aphanipathidae are largely unstudied. Vision is assumed to be absent or minimal given the deep-sea habitat of many black corals and the emphasis on other sensory modalities in related cnidarians.

chemoreception.notes: Chemoreception is likely a primary sense for detecting prey and other environmental cues, as is common in corals. Polp tentacles are likely able to sense chemical gradients.

mechanoreception.notes: Mechanoreception is likely present, allowing the coral to detect water currents and physical contact, as indicated by the description of tentacles and spines. Used for feeding and orientation.
